full_text: In this demonstration, we take a look at the return premium plan that influenced the allocation of policy credits in the previous demonstration. Return premium plans are located with the other plans on the administration tab. I click the arrow icon. Now I select return premium plans on the business settings submenu. Currently, there is only one plan, the default return premium plan, which is shipped with BillingCenter. Let's take a look at it. First, we see the eligible items field. This setting specifies which positive items will be paid during credit allocation. On this plan, the only items that are eligible to be paid by a credit are ones that have the same payer and belong to the same policy period and same charge pattern as the credit being allocated. Notice the plan has two return premium handling schemes. Each of these defines the rules for allocating credit. Each name field entry corresponds to a billing instruction type, with the exception of the exception of the other context. So the scheme name cancellation is used for charges from a cancellation billing instruction. The other scheme is used for charges that do not match any other scheme. Every return premium plan must have a scheme named other, which serves as the catch-all scheme. For example, this return premium plan has no scheme that is specifically for policy change, so the other scheme will be used. The other scheme uses the proportional method. This is the scheme BillingCenter used when applying the credit of $300 in the previous demonstration. As we saw, the $300 was allocated proportionally over the eligible invoice items. The cancellation scheme uses the cancellation scheme. The cancellation scheme uses the last to first method. This means for all cancellation billing instructions, BillingCenter will allocate credits starting with most recent eligible items, which are those having the latest placement date. The when to allocate field controls when credit allocation will take place. Both schemes specify on receipt. As we observed in the previous demo, the credit was allocated as soon as BillingCenter received the billing request. Let's go back to the list of return premium plans. BillingCenter is shipped with a default return premium plan. You can modify it directly or clone it to modify a copy of the plan. However, the important thing to remember is the return premium plan with a priority of 1 is the only active return premium plan for the billing system. Whenever a new policy is issued, the active plan is automatically associated with a new policy period. Making a different plan active does not affect existing policy periods. This concludes our short demonstration on return premium plans. Films Films   Films Films     Films   Films               Films Films                     Films Films Films Films Films

segments.text: In this demonstration, we take a look at the return premium plan that influenced the allocation of policy credits in the previous demonstration. Return premium plans are located with the other plans on the administration tab. I click the arrow icon. Now I select return premium plans on the business settings submenu. Currently, there is only one plan, the default return premium plan, which is shipped with BillingCenter. Let's take a look at it.

First, we see the eligible items field. This setting specifies which positive items will be paid during credit allocation. On this plan, the only items that are eligible to be paid by a credit are ones that have the same payer and belong to the same policy period and same charge pattern as the credit being allocated. Notice the plan has two return premium handling schemes. Each of these defines the rules for allocating credit. Each name field entry corresponds to a billing instruction type, with the

exception of the exception of the other context. So the scheme name cancellation is used for charges from a cancellation billing instruction. The other scheme is used for charges that do not match any other scheme. Every return premium plan must have a scheme named other, which serves as the catch-all scheme. For example, this return premium plan has no scheme that is specifically for policy change, so the other scheme will be used.

The other scheme uses the proportional method. This is the scheme BillingCenter used when applying the credit of $300 in the previous demonstration. As we saw, the $300 was allocated proportionally over the eligible invoice items.

The cancellation scheme uses the cancellation scheme. The cancellation scheme uses the last to first method. This means for all cancellation billing instructions, BillingCenter will allocate credits starting with most recent eligible items, which are those having the latest placement date.

The when to allocate field controls when credit allocation will take place. Both schemes specify on receipt. As we observed in the previous demo, the credit was allocated as soon as BillingCenter received the billing request.

Let's go back to the list of return premium plans. BillingCenter is shipped with a default return premium plan. You can modify it directly or clone it to modify a copy of the plan. However, the important thing to remember is the return premium plan with a priority of 1 is the only active return premium plan for the billing system.

Whenever a new policy is issued, the active plan is automatically associated with a new policy period. Making a different plan active does not affect existing policy periods. This concludes our short demonstration on return premium plans.
